variant.question:
The angle of attack transmitter provides an electric signal varying with:
1) the angular position of a wind vane.
2) the deviation between the airplane flight attitude and the path calculated by the inertial unit.
3) a probe differential pressure depending on the variation of the angle of attack.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
The Directive Force...

options.text: is the component of the Earth’s magnetic field which aligns the compass needle.
is zero over the geographical poles.
is about twice as strong on 60°N/S as on the Equator.
equals the vertical component of the Earth’s magnetic field.

variant.question: During a final approach, the flight director is engaged in the G/S mode (tracking the ILS Glide Slope)If the horizontal command bar is deviating upward, it means that

options.text: the pitch angle must be increased.
the pitch angle must be reduced.
the aircraft is above the glide slope.
the aircraft is below the glide slope.

variant.question: Four scenarios of VOR axis interception are represented in the appended annex. The one corresponding to the optimal interception path calculated by a flight director is number :
In a aircraft cockpit, what is shown on the Mode Control Panel (MCP)?

options.text: AP mode
System status by selection
Flight annunciator
Circuit breaker status

variant.question: The flight director indicates you should turn to the right. As you roll right, what happens to the FD?

options.text: The deviation indication adjusts in proportion to the deviation of the localiser path.
It becomes centred if you exceed a 15-degree bank angle.
It continues reading the exact same deviation until the localiser course is intercepted.
Within 10 degrees of capturing the localiser, the flight director will switch to a left roll indication to help you level the aircraft.

variant.question:
The correction of the control surface deflection made by the autopilot calculator in order to keep a given altitude will be all the more significant when the:
1) difference between the attitude necessary to keep the given or reference altitude and the instantaneous attitude is high.
2) variation speed of the difference between the attitude necessary to maintain the altitude and the instantaneous attitude is high.
3) difference between the altitude of reference and the instantaneous altitude is high.
4) variation speed of the difference between the reference altitude and the instantaneous altitude is high.
The combination re-grouping the correct statements is:
A flight Director (FD) indicates a roll to the right. The pilot manually steers in the direction of the command. During the roll, the FD indication...

options.text: adjust the roll command when approaching the required heading.
disappears as soon as a bank angle of at least 15º is reached.

Keeps indicating and will indicate a left turn 10º before the required heading is reached. Initially indicates a right roll and adjusts to indicate a left turn of 10º before the required heading is reached.
keeps indicating a right roll without a change until the required heading is reached.

variant.question: What is shown on the Mode Control Panel (MCP)?

options.text: AP mode.
Flight annunciator.
System status by selection.
Circuit breaker status.

variant.question: A pilot is manually flying an ILS approach. The Flight Director roll bar is to the left of centre, but the ILS raw indicator is to the right. What should the pilot do?

options.text: Switch off the Flight Director and follow the raw data. This indication scenario shows an obvious fault in the system.
Ignore both indicators and revert to visual flight.
Follow the Flight Director, which is indicating the correct course of action to return to the centreline.
Initiate an immediate go around.

variant.question:
The flight guidance system has different modes. Considering the autopilot/flight director, which of the following describes one feature of the go-around mode?
When selected, the go-around mode engages and the aeroplane climbs...

options.text: whether it is below or above the selected missed approach altitude at the point of initiation.
when it is approaching the missed approach point or minimum descent altitude for the approach.
only if the aeroplane is below the selected missed approach altitude and following an ILS.
only if the selected missed approach altitude is above the aeroplane at the point of initiation.

variant.question: Flying manually during a final approach, the flight director system is engaged in the LOC mode (tracking of localizer beam). If the aircraft is left of the Localizer beam, the vertical command bar:

options.text: will be centred if the pilot is applying the correct bank angle in order to return on the Localizer beam.
is automatically centred since the LOC mode is engaged.
deviates to the left, whatever the attitude of the aircraft is.
deviates to the right, whatever the attitude of the aircraft is.

variant.question: Flying manually during a final approach, the flight director system is engaged in the LOC mode (tracking of localizer beam). If the aircraft is right of the Localizer beam, the vertical command bar:

options.text: will be centred if the pilot is applying the correct bank angle in order to return on the Localizer beam.
cannot be centred.
will be centred only when established on the Localizer beam.
is automatically centred since the LOC mode is engaged.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 The attached figure shows a Multifunction Display (MFD) with AFCS controls and Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA). The pilot is performing a commercial air transport VFR flight and the passengers asked to deviate from the planned route. The pilot disengages the autopilot, turns off course and descends to a lower altitude. The Flight Director (FD) at this point indicates that the aircraft is NOT following the planned route. Should the pilot take further action?

options.text: Yes, the FD must either be switched OFF or the pilot must select modes and parameters for the new intended flight path for the FD to give appropriate guidance.
Yes, the autopilot is still engaged and must be disengaged, because the FD indicates that the aeroplane is turning right and climbing to the selected altitude of 3000 ft.
No, the FD will remain ON and automatically change modes to show appropriate guidance for manual flight during the entire time the autopilot remains disengaged.
No, the FMAs will automatically be removed from view and the FD command bar will be centred after a short period of time, unless the pilot returns to the planned route.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 Four scenarios of VOR axis interception are represented in the appended annex. Which one corresponds to the optimal interception path calculated by a flight director?
You are flying manually with the Flight Director (FD) engaged. When both the FD bars cross in the centre of the aircraft symbol, it means that...

options.text: your aircraft is in the optimum attitude computed for the planned flight path.
both the pitch and yaw attitudes of your aircraft are equal to zero.
your aircraft maintains the optimum altitude and heading.
both the pitch and roll attitudes of your aircraft are equal to zero.

variant.question: Which statement is true about the autopilot and flight director modes and their respective selection panel?

options.text: The modes available for the flight director are the same as those available for the autopilot, and the same panel is used for the selection of both.
The modes available for the flight director are the same as those available for the autopilot, but a separate panel is used for their selection.
The modes available for the flight director are different from those available for the autopilot, but the same panel is used for the selection of both.
The modes available for the flight director are different from those available for the autopilot, and a separate panel is used for their selection.

variant.question: When engaging the autopilot with the FDs, the captain cannot see the annunciator on the FMA. What should you do?

options.text: Deselect the FDs.
Fly manually without AP/FD.
Remain with the FDs ON and keep updating the captain by voice.
Change autopilot and give controls to the captain.

variant.question:
During a final approach, the flight director system is engaged in the LOC mode (tracking of localizer beam). The position of the vertical command bar indicates:
1. the position of the aircraft relative to the localizer beam
2. the bank angle of the aircraft
3. the correction to be applied on the bank angle in order to capture and follow the Localizer beam
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

What does the Flight Director (FD) indicate when engaged?
1. Direction of a flight control input required. 
 2. Magnitude of a flight control input required. 
 3. Magnitude of a power input (throttle) required. 
 4. Flap setting required.

options.text: 1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only
1, 2 and 3
3 and 4 only

variant.question: The Pilot Flying (PF) is manually flying using the Flight Director (FD) and on a heading ATC clears the aircraft to fly direct to "POL” which is on the flight planned route 20º right of the current heading and 50 NM away. The Pilot Monitoring (PM) makes the appropriate selections, which are verified by the PF. What should the PF do next?

options.text: Check on the FMA that the NAV mode is engaged, and that the FD commands a turn towards POL If it does NOT, ask the PM to set the heading or track mode and a suitable heading or track.
Check that the FCU NAV button is illuminated. The FD will command a turn towards POL, so follow the FD and wait until the turn is commanded. ATC will expect a delay so will NOT need to be told.

Turn 20º right, ignoring the FD roll command, and check on the ND that the aircraft is tracking towards POL. Check that the FD roll command is catching up with the turn and that the FMA shows NAV lateral mode is engaged.

Turn towards POL, ignoring the FD. If the FD still commands any turn once the aircraft is tracking towards POL, ignore it, as this is common when flying direct to waypoints, and the FD roll command will eventually reduce.

variant.question: During a final approach, the flight director system is engaged in the LOC mode (tracking of Localiser beam). The position of the vertical command bar indicates:

options.text: the correction to be applied to the bank angle in order to capture and follow the Localizer beam.
the bank angle of the aircraft.
the instantaneous deviation between the aircraft position and the Localizer beam.
the position of the aircraft relative to the Localizer beam.

variant.question: Can an autopilot (AP) and flight director (FD) be active at the same time?

options.text: Yes
no, the FD is for manual flight only
Yes, but only if the AP is selected on one side of the cockpit and the FD on the other
Yes, but only if the FMS is in dual mode

variant.question: During a final approach, the flight director system is engaged in the G/S mode (holding of ILS glide slope). The position of the horizontal command bar indicates: - the position of the aircraft relative to the ILS glide slope. - the correction on the pitch to be applied to join and follow the ILS glide slope. - the instantaneous deviation between the aircraft position and the ILS glide slope. The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

options.text: 2 only
1 only

variant.question: In a multi crew aircraft you have a Pilot Flying (PF) and a Pilot Monitoring (PM).What are the roles and responsibilities of each of the pilots?

options.text: PF flies the aircraft or monitors the autopilot, PM has some similar functions, other ancillary functions and does the radios.
PM flies the aircraft or monitors the autopilot, PF has some similar functions, other ancillary functions and does the radios.
PF flies the aircraft or monitors the autopilot, PM has some similar functions, and other ancillary functions.
PM flies the aircraft or monitors the autopilot, PF has some similar functions and other ancillary functions.

The position of the command bars of a flight director enables the pilot to know:
1. the direction and magnitude of the corrections to apply on the controls
2. only the direction of the corrections to apply on the controls
3. the attitude of the aircraft

1) difference between the reference attitude and the instantaneous attitude is high.

3) temperature is low.
4) pressure altitude is high.

1) the attitude.
2) the bank control.

bank angle to reach the selected radial over a minimum distance.
bank angle to intercept the selected radial with a 30° angle.
bank angle to reach the selected radial in minimum time.

variant.question: When intercepting a selected radial, the flight director indicates the:

options.text: optimum instantaneous bank angle to reach the selected radial.
bank angle to reach the selected radial in minimum time.
bank angle to reach the selected radial over a minimum distance.
bank angle 45.

variant.question: A pilot is flying manually with the flight directors engaged, on an assigned heading towards ‘POL’ VOR that is 120 NM away from the current position. Then, the ATC gives the pilot a direct to with a right hand turn, shortening the route to only 90 NM. The pilot monitoring performs his actions, what do you need to do next as a pilot flying?

options.text: You should check the FMA and if the desired modes are not confirmed, ask the pilot monitoring to select the correct heading/track, and cross-check the selection again.
You should initiate a right-hand turn as instructed by the ATC; the flight directors will catch up by the turn.
Considering the current manual flying conditions, you shouldn’t follow the flight director orders.
Order the pilot monitoring to reset the flight directors as they will automatically start the right turn after you initiate it.

variant.question: During a final approach, if the flight director system is engaged in the G/S mode (tracking of ILS Glide Slope), the position of the horizontal command bar indicates:

options.text: the correction to be applied to the pitch angle in order to capture and follow the ILS Glide Slope.
the position of the aircraft relative to the ILS Glide Slope.
the instantaneous deviation between the aircraft position and the ILS Glide Slope.
the pitch angle of the aircraft.

variant.question: An aircraft flies steadily on a heading 270°. The flight director is engaged in the heading select mode (HDG SEL), heading 270° selected. If a new heading 360° is selected, the vertical bar:

options.text: deviates to the right and will be centred as soon as you roll the aircraft to the bank angle calculated by the flight director.
deviates to its right stop as long as the aeroplane is more than 10° off the new selected heading.
disappears, the new heading selection has deactivated the HDG mode.
deviates to the right and remains in that position until the aircraft has reached heading 360°.

variant.question: During a final approach, the flight director is engaged in the LOC mode (tracking the localizer). If the vertical command bar is deviating to the left, it means that the aircraft:

options.text: must be rolled to the left.
is left of the LOC beam.
must be rolled to the right.
is right of the LOC beam.

variant.question: Situation: Flight Director (FD) engaged, HDG hold engaged, ALT hold engaged. The FD command bars indicate a pitch up and a roll to the left. The pilot has to follow the...

options.text: FD command bars.
opposite of the FD command bars, but only if the AFCS is also engaged.
FD command bars, but only if the AFCS is also engaged.
opposite of the FD command bars.

variant.question:
Refer to the annex. 
Considering the diagram n°1, the flight director command bars position indicates that you should:

options.text: bank your aircraft to the left and increase the pitch angle.
bank your aircraft to the right and increase the pitch angle.
bank your aircraft to the right and reduce the pitch angle.
bank your aircraft to the left and reduce the pitch angle.

variant.question: Mode "Localizer ARM" active on Flight Director means:

is centred if the aircraft has a 20° left drift.
cannot be centred.

The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

will be centred only when established on the ILS Glide Slope.

variant.question: Flying manually during a final approach, the flight director system is engaged in the G/S mode (tracking of ILS Glide Slope). If the aircraft is below the ILS Glide Slope, the horizontal command bar:

variant.question: Which statement is correct for an aircraft with full fly-by-wire flight controls?

options.text: Pitch trim is achieved by moving the horizontal tail section without trim control input, but by computer calculation to relieve continuous pilot pitch control.
Pitch trim is achieved by moving the horizontal tail section by trimming the plane by pilot input on the trim control system.
Pitch trim is achieved by moving only the elevator section by trimming the plane by pilot input on the trim control system.
Pitch trim is achieved by moving only the elevator section without trim control input, but by computer calculation to relieve continuous pilot pitch control.

options.text: pitch and roll commands for use by the human or autopilot.
flight path commands for use by the Flight Management System (FMS).
attitude commands for use by the Stability Augmentation System (SAS).
rate commands for use by the parallel actuators.

variant.question: The purpose of a flight director is to

options.text: reduce the pilots workload by presenting data in the form of control commands.
convey air traffic control information to the pilot.
provide an automatic landing system function.
automatically steer the aircraft to waypoints selected on the CDU.

pitch angle only.
pitch and/or bank angles, and yaw.

to join a desired track with a constant bank angle of 35°.

the position of the aircraft.

path permitting reaching a selected radial in minimum time.

it is not possible to remove them on some types of flight director systems.
autopilot must be first engaged before removing them.

ALT deviation only

only one autopilot channel must be selected ON.

three channels: pitch, roll and yaw.

three channels: pitch, roll and side slipping.

the vertical bar is associated with the pitch channel.

are only displayed when flying manually.

are displayed only when the autopilot is engaged.

options.text: Compares the current attitude with the computed attitude.
Computes the required attitude for the autopilot synchronisation.

options.text: indicates the manoeuvres to execute, in order to achieve or maintain a flight attitude.
enables the measurement of deviation from a given position.

options.text: The available modes and the control panel are the same for both the FD and the AFCS.
The FD and the AFCS have different modes and control panels.
The available modes are the same, but the AFCS control panel is different to that of the FD.
The FD and the AFCS share the same control panel, but the available modes are different.

options.text: guides the pilot towards a selected flight path when manually flying.
is the set of servo actuators that actually do the control movement.
computes the FMS performance data using the autopilot system.

Considering a flight director of the command bars type:
1. the vertical bar is always associated with the roll channel
2. the vertical bar may be associated with the pitch channel
3. the horizontal bar may be associated with the roll channel
4. the horizontal bar is always associated with the pitch channel

options.text: moving either the Captain's or the First Officer's Flight Director switch to ON.
disengaging all autopilot channels.

variant.question: What is the main purpose of the flight data monitoring?

options.text: To record systems status and flight conditions and automatically send reports to the company for investigation and training.
To record systems status and flight conditions and issue alerts and/or warnings to flight crew as soon as predetermined thresholds have been reached.
To record systems status and flight conditions in order to generate automatic checklists both normal and abnormal.
To record systems status and flight conditions and automatically send reports to the authority.

variant.question: What is the main purpose of the flight monitoring system?

options.text: Record systems status and flight conditions and automatically send reports to the company for investigation and training.
Record systems status and flight conditions in order to generated automatic checklists both normal and abnormal.
Record systems status and flight conditions and automatically send reports to the authority.
